bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1900

div1.p: Lazear reports that the yellow fever epidemic is waning. Reed, Carroll and he will study malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1900
div1.p:
I have been
trying to write to you
for several days. Two
letters came from you
close together. Thank
you very much for the
Fifty dollars. The Dennistan
Ave, house has been
rented for $35 a month.
The Jess has succeeded
in having the mortgage
renewed at 4 4/10%
instead of f 5% which
will be a saving of $36
a year. The house on
Park Ave has not been
rented. Unlucky the
man who has
anything in Baltimore.

I am glad you are
over your to tonsilitis.
It is not uncommon
here.

The yellow fever epidemic
seems to be over as there
have been no new cases
for a week. All the
Americans were compelled
to leave town and camp
out. Then were only
twenty-seven cases in
all but it caused a
lot of hard work as
it was necessary to
stop it before it got among the
soldiers.

Drs. Reed and Carroll are now here
and we have laid out a very extensive
plan of work. Some time next week
we make a trip to Cienfuegos and
Cardenas to study malaria.

I am glad you do not have to
eat in the large dining room.
Could you go to Annisquam a
week before the sixteenth? I would
feel easier if I knew you were
there.

It was very sad about Mrs. Garland's
children. I suppose Aunt Kate
was very much shocked and
that Thomas will do without his
rifle for a while.
